bug.short_desc: [working sets] Improve "Edit Working-Set" Dialog

long_desc.thetext:
Adding new files to a working set is really a pain:
I have to edit the working set and browse until I reach the package or file I want to add.
This could be done more easily from the Package Explorer or Editor Context menu.
Sometimes, there is already a "Remove from working set" entry, but not for all items. And the "Add to..." working set is completely missing.
This would be useful in the "Other projects..." tree or even in another working set.
While this is "only" an enhancement, I would regard this as a higher priority.
Thanks, Jrg
Not sure if this is JDT or should be handled by Platform/UI. Feel free to punt back.

Adding a 'Add to Working Set' action is a good idea. But maybe we should just improve the 'Edit Working Set' dialog which is a pain to work in if you have many projects. I also have problems finding entries as scrolling is involved and expanding a node covers the whole screen.
First ideas: - Avoid the checkbox tree but use a list with 'add/remove' - Two pane dialog with all elements and already added entries (similar to PDEs Plugin Import)
I think we should look at that for 3.3
*** Bug 154589 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

Improving the Edit Working Set dialog is definitely a good idea.
But this use case happens occasionally:
* Editing a file in the working set * This file uses a class, interface etc not in the working set * Now I have to change this dependent class. * It is open in the editor view, and in "Other projects" of the Package Explorer.
Now I would like to have a quick way to add it to the working set. Opening the "Edit Working Set" dialog and browsing to the file is too cumbersome, even if the dialog has been improved.

Would be good to look at as polish item for 3.3
Bug 182100 is about the 'Add to...' action
Created an attachment (id=77157) fix

fixed > I20070821-0800
Mmm, that's better, we should do the same for the edit resource working set dialog...

bug.short_desc: intermediate state for the check box and radio button

long_desc.thetext:
is it possible to control the look & feel for the check mark and the rectangle box around it? e.g., if we have to implement a semi-checked state as available for "Wrap" and "Merge" check boxes in the "Format" dialog in MS Excel. This is shown if you select multiple cells in MS excel and some of them have wrap enabled and some not OR some are merged and some are not.
It should not be confused with a disabled check box as a disabled check box does not show the focus and also its caption is grayed out.
If you click on this semi-checked state, it will show a fully check state first, i.e., white background and black check mark. Second click will remove the check mark. Third check will again show the semi-checked state.
If currently this is not available, then is there any work-around to achieve this?
I have a similar requirement for Radio button also.
thnx.

Created an attachment (id=48077) sample image for semi-checked state.
attaching an image for the sample.
thnx.

Please see bug 22261 for the check box part.
In the absence of greyed radio buttons, one could use a combo box with some kind of "<Mixed>" entry.

bug.short_desc: [modulecore] JavaArtifactEditModel leaks every time you open and close web.xml editor

long_desc.thetext:
Since the ArtifactEditModel has a command stack, leak of the instance causes leak of commands executed while web.xml editor has been active.
Looking around code, org.eclipse.wst.common.componentcore.internal.ArtifactEditModel class adds its instance as a listener of facetProj in its constructor, and dispose() method of the class has code to remove itself from listeners of facetProj. However, the problem is that the dispose() method is never called when closing web.xml editor (when WebArtifactEdit is released).

I'm dupping this defect - as I am looking into the problem of cleaning up editmodel instances on project delete....
When Editors are closed, the editmodel may be released but not disposed because of our cache. The real test here would be seeing more leaks after opening and closing the editor the 2nd, 3rd ... time
I'll be fixing the problem of cleaning up the cached editmodels on project delete.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 153601 ***
issue tracked, fixed and closed through 153601.
Closing as verified.

bug.short_desc: [rptlibrary] Data Set Property Binding not usable in the report

long_desc.thetext:
Hi,
If you create a Data Set with a "Property Binding" in a rptlibrary, the bind isn't realised at runtime in the rptreport.
Sample:
rptlibrary Query : SELECT * FROM myTable Property Binding: "SELECT * FROM myTable WHERE id = " + params["p_id"]
In the rptreport the 'Query' is always used when you display the report.
Best Regards
Pascal

This is the same issue as Bug 131304. The property binding feature was not designed to be portable from a library to a report design.
I am keeping this bug open to one of the following can be done (1) Disable property binding editor when working on a rptlibrary file, if we decide to keep the original design. (2) Enhance BIRT to allow property bindings to be copied (there are valid use cases for this, e.g., both report parameters and data objects come from a library, and there are inherent binding relationships between the report params and data objects)
schedule for 2.2.1 for continue consideration of this enh.
*** Bug 194748 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
*** Bug 203137 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

The data set/data source property bindings are association properties. They associate a data set/data source with report-specific local resources (e.g., report parameters). They are therefore not part of the data set/data source definition (even though you edit these in the data set/source editor). Therefore if a data source and data set is copied from one report to another, or if they come from a rptlibrary, the property bindings are not automatically carried over.

(In reply to comment #5) > The data set/data source property bindings are association properties. They > associate a data set/data source with report-specific local resources (e.g., > report parameters). They are therefore not part of the data set/data source > definition (even though you edit these in the data set/source editor). > Therefore if a data source and data set is copied from one report to another, > or if they come from a rptlibrary, the property bindings are not automatically > carried over. >
I have a few comments/questions. In an earlier reply you said this was a valid use case. Since then was it decided that it wasn't a valid use case?
Also, I just tried the latest stable build, birt-runtime-2.2.1-S20070914, with my test report in Bug 203137 https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=203137 and it's working. Does that mean it was fixed, or is this just the side effect of some other change? Should I anticipate that this behavior will make it to 2.2.1?
Thanks

(In reply to comment #6) > (In reply to comment #5) > > The data set/data source property bindings are association properties. They > > associate a data set/data source with report-specific local resources (e.g., > > report parameters). They are therefore not part of the data set/data source > > definition (even though you edit these in the data set/source editor). > > Therefore if a data source and data set is copied from one report to another, > > or if they come from a rptlibrary, the property bindings are not automatically > > carried over. > > > > I have a few comments/questions. > In an earlier reply you said this was a valid use case. Since then was it > decided that it wasn't a valid use case? > > Also, I just tried the latest stable build, birt-runtime-2.2.1-S20070914, with > my test report in Bug 203137 > https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=203137 and it's working. Does > that mean it was fixed, or is this just the side effect of some other change? > Should I anticipate that this behavior will make it to 2.2.1? > > Thanks >
Seems I spoke too soon. I couldn't get the actual reports to work correctly on birt-runtime-2.2.1-S20070914. But the other comment still stands. It is a valid use case.

bug.short_desc: [JavaMetaModel] Handling Arrays as Collection

long_desc.thetext:
In Forum Thread http://www.openarchitectureware.org/forum/viewtopic.php?forum=2&showtopic=1901 it was requested that arrays are handled as collections for the JavaBeans metamodel.
Example: FOREACH this.getMethods() AS e getMethods() returns an array, FOREACH does not work.
fixed by implicitly converting array return values to lists

bug.short_desc: Support @Nullable and @NotNull Annotation

long_desc.thetext:
IntelliJ Idea supports the annotations @Nullable and @NotNull on methods to indicate that the methods can or can not return null. This is very usefull for a static code analysis as it can point at programming errors (failures to check for null values).
It would be nice if Eclipse supported those annotations as well. From what I've read from the URL the IDEA team is interested in getting this annotations into the JDK, so it seems to me that they don't mind interoperability in this case.
(Sorry if this is a dupe, I've searched and didn't find any such request, which I find surprising, since it's a very nice feature IMHO and is worthy of discussion at least).

I would consider that this bug merely supports the option described in comment #4 of bug 126551.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 126551 ***

(In reply to comment #1) > I would consider that this bug merely supports the option described in comment > #4 of bug 126551. > > *** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 126551 *** >
Can you explain why checkin with annotations is the same as interprocedural analysis (bug 126551) ?
More on annotations: - JSR 305: Annotations for Software Defect Detection http://jcp.org/en/jsr/detail?id=305
- FindBugs: @CheckForNull, @CheckReturnValue, @NonNull, @Nullable http://findbugs.sourceforge.net/manual/annotations.html
- ItelliJ IDEA: @Nullable and @NotNull http://www.jetbrains.com/idea/documentation/howto.html

(In reply to comment #2) > Can you explain why checkin with annotations is the same as interprocedural > analysis (bug 126551) ? My intent was not to suggest that this was the same. In fact, I intended to indicate that any action we might take on this subject (making use of annotations in relationship with null checks) would be considered in the context of the umbrella bug 126551, which is meant to track our inter-procedural analysis at large. Hence we would see this as a 'planning' relationship, rather than a strictly semantic relationship. Hope this helps (while I am conscious that the current status of bug 126551 may well not satisfy you).

(In reply to comment #3) > My intent was not to suggest that this was the same. In fact, I intended to > indicate that any action we might take on this subject (making use of > annotations in relationship with null checks) would be considered in the > context of the umbrella bug 126551, which is meant to track our > inter-procedural analysis at large. Hence we would see this as a 'planning' > relationship, rather than a strictly semantic relationship. > Hope this helps (while I am conscious that the current status of bug 126551 may > well not satisfy you).
Thanks for the explanation. You guessed right, the status of bug 126551 is RESOLVED-WONTFIX. If this BUG is not rejected, is it possible to re-open it ?
You could. I am telling you that it will change anything though. I guess that the item may be considered sometime in 3.4 if it gathers enough support.

(In reply to comment #5) > You could. I am telling you that it will change anything though. I guess that > the item may be considered sometime in 3.4 if it gathers enough support.
re-opened as bug 186342 .

For existing, open tasks the npe is followed by an 'Unhandled event loop exception' - Eclipse says a stack trace isn't available.
If I try to run an existing JIRA query, I get the following (same line causing the problem):
java.lang.NullPointerException at org.eclipse.mylar.internal.jira.JiraRepositoryConnector.updateTaskDetails(JiraRepositoryConnector.java:259) at org.eclipse.mylar.internal.jira.JiraRepositoryConnector.performQuery(JiraRepositoryConnector.java:178) at org.eclipse.mylar.tasks.ui.SynchronizeQueryJob.run(SynchronizeQueryJob.java:84) at org.eclipse.core.internal.jobs.Worker.run(Worker.java:58)

Mik will want to look at this one but he is away at the moment. He'll probably get to this early next week. In the mean time, does your Jira server have custom priority levels? It looks like this could result if the server returns a priority level outside of 1 - 5.

It looks like a custom priority thing to me too. Perhaps you need an 'other' priority? It might be possible to guess a mylar priority value for custom priorities based on their position in the list of available priorities (assuming they come back ordered).
Ed,

Sorry, submitted to soon. I resolved this by making the code robust to unknown priority levels and setting them as default. If an unrecognized priority is processed it will be printed to the log. A dev build with this update should be available on Monday. If you could try that out and let us know the priorities that you're seeing logged that would be helpful. Or just let us know what the JIRA web UI lists as the priorities and we can consider handling customized priority levels more gracefully.

bug.short_desc: [quick assist] NEW: Convert to StringBuffer/StringBuilder

long_desc.thetext:
I think we better start this as a quick assist. If it turns out well, we can add a clean up that can do it on more than a file.
Problem will be if the concatenated string is not an assignment. foo(otherCall(), "Hello " + myName() + "!"); would have to be transformed to: foo(otherCall(), new StringBuilder().append("Hello ").append(myName()).append("!").toString());
to make sure that the call order of otherCall() and myName() is not changed.
I'm also not sure if users really want all occurrences of string concatenations to be transformed, or only for a certain number of operands.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 36350 ***

bug.short_desc: StaticGraphViewerImpl.java not easy to subclass

long_desc.thetext:
the StaticGraphViewerImpl could make it easier for subclassers to access functionality by refactoring some methods into smaller bits that could then be overridden by subclassess.
For me there was the need to change applyLayoutInternal and extract the two methods: calculateSizeOfLayout and handleOverlap
additionally it would be good to have methods to add and remove a progresslistener to the layoutAlgorithm. As the layout is a private field, it cannot be directly accessed by a subclass.
see attached patch for a refactoring proposal

Created an attachment (id=48084) refactoring proposal
see first comment

Created an attachment (id=48095) changed patch to include one more change
removed tight coupling of setting style with setStyle and setting the layoutAlgorithm
layoutAlgorithm is initialized in the constructor and can be set using setLayoutAlgorithm. setStyle does not set the layoutAlgorithm anymore

StaticGraphViewerImpl is in an internal package, so it was never intended to be subclassed. I'm interested in knowing exactly why you wanted to subclass it, though. What extra functionality did you need from the impl?

It all started when I subclassed StaticGraphViewer which is in a public package. I am building a call graph view and for that added zoom actions, an outline view for views using a thumbnail of the view for navigation and I am running the creation of the layout in a job with progress monitor. StaticGraphViewerImpl didn't seem to offer that functionality, which is why was subclassing it.
What do you suggest should/could be done? It would be helpful if it was possible to have your own GraphicalViewerImpl and set the viewer in the StaticGraphViewer.
Did you want to add zooming to the static graph? Was that the problem? Have you tried to use the nested graph viewer?

Created an attachment (id=48166) screenshot of my call graph view
yes, adding zoom to the static viewer was a problem, but not the only one. The graphical outline was another one which seemed to require changes to the viewerImpl.
No, I haven't tried out the nestedViewer, as the example view showing the workspace was really slow the last time I've tried it out which was months ago. And my call graph object are not really nested structures, even though they could be represented in a nested way by grouping methods together, but that is not the aim currently.

So, what you basically need, it seems, is the ability to zoom in the static viewer (not on a particular node, but just to get more detail). This is a good feature request. Would you mind if we closed this bug, and openned a new one with the feature request? Then, we can work on that. I'll take a look at your refactored code too, to see if it will help out with the feature.
You can continue to subclass the internal files, but be aware that they'll be easily broken. Though, that seems to be the general state of ZEST right now, as it is under heavy development ;-).
I'm opening a new bug report to make a feature request for zooming in the static viewer. This bug can be closed after that.
This bug should be closed. Zooming was added in bug #156286
Do you both agree we can close this?
yes, I'll open other bug reports if i would like changes to StaticGraphViewerImpl, rather then subclassing it.
I don't really like calling this bug "invalid", but that is the best I could think of. It is not recommended that StaticGraphViewerImpl be sublcassed. The but is resolved.
